content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Michael Romero: Well, I was born in Hoboken, New Jersey, and I've spent most of my life in the Middle Atlantic region. I grew up in a close-knit Italian-American family, and my parents always emphasized the importance of education and hard work. My father worked as a mechanic, and my mother was a school administrator—both had only high school degrees, but they were determined to give me and my siblings every opportunity. I remember my mother always saying, 'If you work hard, you can achieve anything.' I took that to heart. I was the first in my family to go to college, and I earned a bachelor's degree in business administration. I've been working full time ever since, and while I've never married or had children, I've always stayed connected to my roots—whether it's through my faith as a Catholic or my love for Italian food and language. I still live in Hoboken, though I've moved around a bit within the state over the years. Life has been good, and I feel lucky to have had the opportunities I've had.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Michael Romero: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 22, right after I graduated from college with my bachelor's in business administration. I had two main options: take a job at a local bank in Hoboken or move to Chicago to work for a startup that was expanding. The bank job was stable, safe, and close to home, which made sense given my family's expectations. But the startup offered a chance to be part of something new, something innovative. I was torn because I didn't want to disappoint my parents, but I also felt like I needed to take a risk to find my own path. In the end, I chose the startup. It was a tough decision, and I remember telling my mom, 'I know this is scary, but I have to try.' That experience taught me a lot about resilience, adaptability, and the importance of trusting my instincts. It also helped me realize that while family support is crucial, sometimes you have to carve your own way. That choice ultimately shaped who I am today—more independent, more confident, and more open to change.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Michael Romero: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I spent weeks talking to my parents, my friends, and even a few mentors I had from college. I weighed the pros and cons of each path, and I knew that if I stayed in Hoboken, I'd be comfortable, but maybe not challenged. I wanted more than comfort—I wanted to grow. So I made the decision to take the risk, and I told myself that if it didn't work out, I could always come back. In a way, it felt like a test of my own courage. I didn't just choose the startup; I chose to believe in myself, and that belief has stayed with me ever since.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Michael Romero: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during that time would have made a big difference. My mother was incredibly supportive, but she also wanted stability for me. I remember talking to a professor from college who had taken a similar risk when he left his hometown to work in tech. He shared his story with me, and it gave me the confidence to see that taking a leap wasn't just reckless—it could be transformative. I also reached out to a few friends who had worked in startups, and their insights helped me understand what I was getting into. In the end, while I made the choice myself, I don't think I would have had the clarity or courage without those conversations. It's a reminder that even when we feel like we're on our own, there are people and resources out there who can help guide us through tough decisions.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Michael Romero: As it stands, I'm currently single and don't have any children. I've never married, though I've had a few meaningful relationships over the years. I always valued connection and companionship, but I also found that my career and personal goals often took precedence. I've never felt the need to rush into a relationship or settle for something that didn't feel right. My family is still very important to me—my parents are in their late 60s now, and I make it a point to visit them often, especially during holidays or big family events. I also have a younger sister who lives in Philadelphia, and we stay in touch regularly. While I don't have a partner right now, I don't see that as a lack—it's more of a choice. I enjoy my independence, and I like the freedom to focus on my work, my hobbies, and my community. I'm involved with a few local Catholic organizations, and I find that volunteering and staying connected to my faith gives me a sense of purpose that I really value.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my journey has been shaped by the values instilled in me by my family, the choices I've made, and the support I've received along the way. From my childhood in Hoboken to the pivotal decision to leave for Chicago, each step has been a reflection of my desire to grow, to challenge myself, and to stay true to who I am. The crossroads I faced at 22 wasn't just about a job—it was about defining my identity and embracing the unknown. I'm grateful for the people who helped me see the possibilities, and I'm proud of the person I've become through it all. Even now, as I continue to live independently and stay connected to my roots, I carry with me the lessons of resilience, faith, and the importance of making choices that align with my own sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Michael Romero: My immediate family includes my parents, my younger sister, and my two older brothers. My parents have always been the heart of our family, and even though they didn't have advanced degrees, they worked tirelessly to provide for us. My brothers, both of whom are married with children now, have always been supportive of my decisions, even when they didn't fully understand them. I remember when I decided to move to Chicago, one of my brothers joked that I was 'running away from the family business,' but in reality, I was just trying to find my own path. My relationship with my siblings is warm and affectionate—we may not see each other as often as I'd like, but we always make time for each other during holidays and family gatherings. I also have a few cousins who I grew up with, and we still keep in touch. Family has always been a cornerstone of my life, and even though I've made choices that diverged from the traditional path, I know I can always count on them.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Michael Romero: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Antonio, a childhood friend from Hoboken who also left the area for opportunities in Chicago. We reconnected when I moved there, and we've been close ever since. He's a graphic designer, and he's always been the creative counterbalance to my more analytical side. We've been through a lot together—late-night talks, career changes, even a few bad decisions. I think friendship is about showing up for each other, and Antonio has always done that. There's also a group of coworkers from the startup I joined back in my 20s who I still keep in touch with. We don't see each other as often as we'd like, but we have a strong bond from those early days of building something from nothing. As for romantic partners, I've had a few meaningful relationships, but none that I felt were the right fit for the long term. I've always believed in taking time to find the right person, and I think that patience has served me well. I'm not in a rush, and I'm content with where I am right now.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Michael Romero: I currently live in a quiet neighborhood in Hoboken, just a few blocks away from the Hudson River. It's a mix of older brick buildings and newer apartments, with a lot of small businesses and restaurants that give the area a real sense of community. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for decades. The building has a lot of character—original hardwood floors, high ceilings, and a small courtyard in the back where a few of the residents gather for coffee or just to chat. I love the proximity to the river; it's a peaceful place to walk in the mornings, and I often sit there with my coffee and just watch the boats go by. Hoboken has changed a lot over the years, becoming more diverse and more vibrant, but I still feel like I'm part of the same community I grew up in. There's a strong sense of history here, and I appreciate that. I also enjoy the walkability of the neighborhood—most of the shops, cafes, and even the local library are within a 10-minute walk. It's not the most exciting place in the world, but it's comfortable, and I've built a life here that feels meaningful to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Michael Romero: I definitely feel safe here. Hoboken has always been a tight-knit community, and even though it's grown a lot over the years, there's still a strong sense of familiarity and mutual respect among the residents. I've never had any issues with crime or safety, and I think that's partly because of the way people look out for each other. If someone is walking alone at night, you can usually count on someone from the neighborhood to be around. I also appreciate how the local police department works closely with the community, holding regular meetings and being approachable. It's not just about the absence of danger—it's about the presence of care and connection. That makes me feel secure, not just in my home, but in the people who live around me.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Michael Romero: Living here in Hoboken has definitely had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the upside, I love the sense of community and the way people know each other. It's not uncommon to see neighbors waving or stopping by to check in, especially during the holidays or when someone's having a tough time. The location is also a big plus—being close to Manhattan means I have access to cultural events, job opportunities, and a vibrant nightlife without having to live in the city itself. But there are downsides too. The cost of living has gone up significantly over the years, and while I'm doing okay financially, it's not always easy to keep up with rent and maintenance. There's also the occasional frustration with the slower pace of change—sometimes I feel like the city is stuck in a time capsule, and I wonder if it will ever fully embrace the diversity and innovation that's happening elsewhere. Still, I've made peace with it. I've built a life here, and I've come to appreciate the quiet stability and the familiar rhythms of Hoboken. It's not perfect, but it's home.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my current life and relationships continue to reflect the values and choices I've made over the years. When talking about my family, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for the support and love they've always given me, even when my path diverged from theirs. Being single and childless isn't a lack, but a choice—one that allows me to focus on my independence, my work, and my faith. My friendships, like the one with Antonio, remind me of the importance of connection and loyalty, and they've been a steady presence in my life. Living in Hoboken now feels like coming full circle, as it's where I started, and where I've built a life that feels meaningful and secure. The sense of community here, the safety, and the familiarity all contribute to a life that, while not without its challenges, feels deeply rooted and fulfilling.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Michael Romero: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though I do vary my routine a bit depending on work and personal commitments. I work full time as a business analyst for a mid-sized company, so most of my days start around 8 a.m. I usually have a quick breakfast—something simple like coffee and a croissant from the bakery down the street—then head into the office. My workday is pretty structured, with meetings, emails, and project management tasks. I try to take a lunch break around noon, and I often walk to the park or sit by the river for a few minutes to clear my head. In the afternoons, I get back into the flow of work, and I usually wrap up around 5 p.m. On some days, I'll go to the gym or meet up with Antonio for a drink or a bite to eat. On weekends, I like to slow down. I might attend a Mass at the local church, volunteer at the food pantry, or just spend time reading or cooking. I've gotten pretty good at making Italian dishes—my nonna's lasagna recipe is one of my favorites. I also enjoy going to the library or browsing the local bookstores. It's not an extravagant life, but it's steady, and I find comfort in that rhythm. There's something about having a routine that helps me feel grounded, especially in a world that can feel so fast-paced and unpredictable.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Michael Romero: I work as a business analyst for a mid-sized financial services company, and I'm typically on the clock from around 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. My role involves analyzing data, helping to streamline processes, and supporting decision-making for our clients. I've been in this position for nearly a decade now, and while it's not the most glamorous job, it's stable and allows me to use the skills I developed in college. I've always had a knack for numbers and problem-solving, which made business administration a natural fit. What I like most about my job is the challenge—it keeps my mind sharp and gives me a sense of accomplishment when I see the impact of my work. I also appreciate the flexibility it offers, especially since it allows me to maintain my independence and stay involved in my community. On some days, I'll work late if a project is due, but I make it a point to leave on time so I can enjoy the rest of my evening, whether it's with a good book, a meal with friends, or just a quiet walk by the river.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Michael Romero: Outside of work and my personal life, I also have a few routines that keep me grounded. Every Sunday morning, I attend Mass at the local Catholic church, which has been a constant in my life since I was a child. It's not just about religion for me—it's about community, tradition, and finding a moment of peace in the week. After Mass, I usually stop by the food pantry where I volunteer a few hours each month. It's a small way to give back, and it reminds me of the values my parents instilled in me. I also have a habit of writing in a journal, mostly just to reflect on my day or jot down ideas. It's something I started in college, and it's become a way for me to process my thoughts and stay connected to who I am. I don't do it every day, but when I do, it feels like a conversation with myself, and that's something I really value.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Michael Romero: One recent change to my daily routine has been taking up gardening in the small space I have on my balcony. I've always enjoyed being outdoors, but I never really had the time or space to dedicate to something like this before. A few months ago, I bought a few potted herbs and some tomatoes, and it's been a nice way to slow down and connect with nature. It's surprising how much satisfaction you get from watching something grow, especially when you're the one nurturing it. I've also started making a point to go to bed a bit earlier, which has helped me feel more rested and focused during the day. I think part of that shift came from realizing how much I value my time with friends and family, and I want to be present for those moments. It's not a huge change, but these small adjustments have made a real difference in how I feel overall.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Michael Romero: Actually, I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them. I've always chosen to focus on my career, my faith, and my independence, and while I've had meaningful relationships over the years, I've never felt the need to settle down or start a family. That said, I've always been close to my own parents and siblings, and I think that's shaped my perspective on family life. I've seen how my parents balanced work and family, and while I admire their dedication, I've always felt that my path was different. I enjoy the freedom that comes with not having children—it allows me to travel, take on new projects, and spend time with friends and family on my own terms. I don't see my choice as a lack, but rather as a conscious decision to live a life that aligns with my values and priorities.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines are deeply connected to the values and choices I've made over the years. My work as a business analyst provides stability and purpose, while my routines—like attending Mass, volunteering, and journaling—help me stay grounded and connected to my roots. The small changes I've made, like gardening and going to bed earlier, reflect my ongoing desire to live intentionally and find joy in the simple things. Even though I don't have children, my life is rich with family, friendships, and community, and I feel a deep sense of fulfillment in the life I've built for myself in Hoboken.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Michael Romero: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm in pretty good shape for someone in my 40s. I try to stay active, and while I don't have a strict fitness regimen, I do make an effort to walk or bike whenever I can. I've always been a bit of a sedentary worker, sitting at a desk most of the day, but I've started to incorporate more movement into my routine—like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or doing a few stretches during breaks. I also try to eat reasonably well, though I'm not perfect. I love Italian food, and I enjoy cooking at home, which helps me avoid the fast-food trap. I do have a few health concerns, though. I've been dealing with mild hypertension for a few years now, which my doctor says is manageable with diet, exercise, and medication. I also have some occasional back pain from sitting for long periods, but I've started doing some light yoga to help with that. Overall, I feel pretty healthy, and I try to take my health seriously because I know it's something you can't take for granted. I also make sure to get regular check-ups and stay up to date on vaccinations. It's not always easy to prioritize health when life gets busy, but I've learned that small, consistent habits make a big difference over time.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Michael Romero: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that incorporates small, manageable habits—like walking to work, cooking meals at home, and making time for Mass and journaling. These things aren't just about health; they're about grounding myself and staying connected to what matters. What makes it harder, though, is the temptation to slip into old patterns, especially when work gets busy or I'm not in the mood to cook. I've caught myself reaching for convenience foods or skipping my evening walk on a stressful day. But I've learned that consistency is key, and even on the days when I don't feel like it, doing something—anything—helps keep me on track. It's also the support from friends and family that makes a difference. When Antonio or one of my siblings checks in, it reminds me to take care of myself, and that encouragement goes a long way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Michael Romero: In the past two years, I've been managing my hypertension more consistently, and I've actually seen some improvement in my blood pressure readings thanks to a combination of diet, exercise, and medication. I started working with a nutritionist a year ago, and that's helped me make better food choices—more vegetables, less processed food, and I've cut back on salt, which has made a noticeable difference. I also joined a local yoga class a few months back, and that's been great for my back pain. I used to dismiss yoga as something for people who were more flexible, but I've found that even gentle stretches have helped me feel more balanced and less stiff. The only real challenge has been staying consistent with the yoga, especially during colder months when I'd rather stay indoors. But overall, I feel like I'm in a better place health-wise than I was a couple of years ago. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to take it one day at a time.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Michael Romero: Honestly, my health hasn't really gotten in the way of my work or daily life. I've always been someone who tries to manage things proactively, and while I've had my share of challenges—like the back pain and hypertension—I've never let them define me or hold me back. I've learned to listen to my body and make adjustments when needed. For example, if I'm feeling stiff or tired, I'll take a short walk or do some light stretching during the day instead of pushing through. I also make sure to schedule regular check-ups and follow my doctor's advice, which has helped me stay on top of things. I know that if I neglect my health, it could eventually impact my work or my ability to enjoy life, so I try to stay ahead of potential issues. In the end, I see my health as part of the bigger picture—something I need to take care of so I can continue doing the things I love, like volunteering, spending time with family, and staying active in my community.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Michael Romero: Over the past year, I've felt a deep sense of contentment and stability in my life, even though there have been moments of uncertainty. I've been reflecting a lot on where I am and how far I've come, especially as I've reached the age of 40. It's interesting how time passes, and how the choices I made in my 20s have shaped the person I am today. I've been more intentional about my health, which has given me a greater sense of control over my well-being. I've also found joy in the small things—like tending to my balcony garden, cooking meals for friends, or just sitting by the river with a good book. Professionally, I've been in a good place at work, and I feel like I've found a balance between my career and my personal life. I've also been more involved in my community, whether it's through volunteering or attending events at the church. There have been challenges, of course—like the occasional loneliness that comes with being single and childless—but I've come to see those moments as reminders of the freedom and independence I've chosen. Overall, I feel grounded, grateful, and at peace with the life I've built for myself.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and daily habits are intertwined with my overall sense of well-being and purpose. Taking up gardening on my balcony has been a small but meaningful change that has brought me closer to nature and given me a sense of accomplishment. It's a reminder that even in the simplest of ways, we can find joy and fulfillment. At the same time, I've come to understand that staying healthy isn't just about physical fitness—it's about making consistent choices that support my body and mind, like eating well, moving regularly, and taking time for reflection. I've also learned that it's okay to struggle with consistency, and that the support of friends and family plays a vital role in keeping me on track. My hypertension and back pain are reminders that health is something I need to take seriously, and I'm grateful for the small improvements I've made over the past year. These changes, while not dramatic, have helped me feel more in control of my life and more connected to the values that have always guided me.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Michael Romero: I think I've been fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do. That's not to say I haven't had my share of stress or moments of doubt—life has its ups and downs, and there have been times when I've felt overwhelmed, especially during busy work periods or when I've been reflecting on my choices. But I've always found ways to cope, whether it's through my faith, my friendships, or the simple act of taking a walk by the river. I've also learned to recognize when I need to slow down and take a step back, which has helped me avoid getting stuck in negative patterns. I think part of it is having a strong support system and a sense of purpose. Volunteering, staying connected to my community, and maintaining my routines all help me feel grounded. I know not everyone has that, and I'm grateful for the tools I've developed over the years to stay mentally and emotionally balanced.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Michael Romero: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, reflection, and connection. My parents are both in their late 60s now, and while they're still active, they've started to slow down a bit more. My mother has been more involved with her church group, which brings her joy, and my father has taken up woodworking as a hobby—something he always wanted to try but never had the time for. I see them a few times a month, and even though we don't live close, we make it a point to have meaningful conversations, whether it's about their lives, my work, or just catching up on the latest news. My sister, who lives in Philadelphia, has been going through a bit of a career transition, and I've been there for her through that. We've had some deep talks about what we want from life and how we're both figuring out what comes next. It's been a reminder that even though we're all at different stages, family is still the foundation that holds us together. I feel lucky to have them in my life, and I know they're proud of the path I've chosen, even if it's not the one they expected for me.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Michael Romero: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life. Being Catholic is more than just attending Mass on Sundays—it's about the values, the traditions, and the sense of community that come with it. My parents raised me with a deep respect for the faith, and even though I've never been one to attend church every week, I've always found comfort in the rituals and the teachings. I believe in God, and I believe in the importance of prayer, charity, and living with integrity. My faith has been a source of strength for me, especially during difficult times. It's what keeps me grounded, reminds me of where I come from, and gives me a sense of purpose beyond just my work or my personal life. I know not everyone shares my beliefs, and that's okay. What matters is that my faith has shaped who I am, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Michael Romero: To be honest, I'm not really active on social media platforms like Facebook or Instagram. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or even a good phone call over scrolling through feeds. I do use my phone to stay in touch with family and friends—texting, calling, or even using video chat when I can. I think there's value in being present in the moment, and I find that social media can sometimes take away from that. That said, I do follow a few local news pages and community groups on Facebook, just to stay informed about what's happening in Hoboken and the surrounding areas. I also have a few old college friends who I occasionally catch up with through messages, but I don't spend a lot of time on these platforms. For me, it's more about quality over quantity when it comes to staying connected, and I think that's why I've never felt the need to be constantly online.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Michael Romero: Honestly, I don't think I've ever relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I've always found that the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, my church community—are more than enough to help me through challenges. When I've faced difficulties, whether it was a hard work project or a personal loss, it's been the conversations I've had over coffee, the calls I've made to my parents, or the prayers I've said in church that have helped me the most. I know some people find comfort in online communities or support groups, and I respect that. But for me, it's about the relationships I've built over the years, not the likes or shares I might get online. I think that's why I've never felt the need to be constantly connected to social media—it's not that I don't care about staying informed or connected, but I believe in the power of real, meaningful connections over virtual ones.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health and mental well-being have become a priority in my life, especially as I've grown older and more reflective. Over the past two years, I've made conscious efforts to manage my hypertension and back pain, and I've come to see these challenges not as obstacles, but as reminders of the importance of taking care of myself. While I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, I've learned that even small moments of stress or doubt are a natural part of life. What matters most is how I respond to them—through faith, community, and the simple act of staying grounded in my routines. I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends, and I've come to understand that mental and physical health are deeply connected. I've also found comfort in knowing that I'm not alone in my journey, and that even in moments of uncertainty, I have the tools and people around me to help me stay balanced and at peace with who I am.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Michael Romero: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have remained relatively stable, though I've become more aware of how I manage it. I used to push through stress without really acknowledging it, but now I take a more intentional approach. When I feel overwhelmed, I try to step back and do something that grounds me—whether it's attending Mass, going for a walk by the river, or even just sitting quietly with a cup of coffee and my journal. I've also started meditating a little, though I'm not very experienced with it. It's more about breathing deeply and reminding myself that I'm not alone in whatever I'm going through. I've found that talking things out with Antonio or one of my siblings helps a lot, too. They've always been there to listen without judgment, and that support makes a big difference. I think the key for me has been learning to recognize when I need to slow down and take care of myself, rather than trying to power through everything. It's not always easy, but I've come to see it as part of the process—something that helps me stay balanced and at peace with who I am.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Michael Romero: In terms of making ends meet, I've always been pretty careful with my money, especially since I've been living on my own since I was 22. My biggest expenses last month were rent, which takes up a significant chunk of my income, and groceries, especially since I've been cooking more at home and trying to eat healthier. I also have a car payment, insurance, and a few recurring bills like my phone and internet. I try to budget for things like gas and maintenance, but those can be unpredictable. I also set aside some money each month for my volunteer work and church donations, which are important to me. While I'm not rolling in wealth, I've managed to build a stable life for myself, and I feel fortunate that I don't have any major financial stress. I've always believed in living within my means, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay independent and focused on the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Michael Romero: My household spending last month was around $3,500, give or take a few hundred dollars. That's pretty much in line with what I usually spend each month. The largest portion goes to rent, which is about $1,800 for my two-bedroom apartment in Hoboken. Groceries come next, averaging around $600, especially since I've been cooking more at home and trying to eat healthier. My car payment and insurance are another $600 or so, and then there's the usual monthly expenses like phone, internet, and utilities, which add up to about $300. I also set aside around $200 for church donations and volunteer work, which is important to me. I try to save a little each month, so I usually put aside about $300 into a savings account. I don't have a lot of discretionary spending, but I do enjoy the occasional meal out with Antonio or a new book from the library. Overall, I've always been pretty careful with my money, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to live independently and comfortably without any major financial stress.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Michael Romero: We rent our home. I've always preferred renting over owning, mainly because it gives me more flexibility, especially given my career and the possibility of moving for new opportunities. Plus, with the way the real estate market has been in Hoboken, buying a home would be a big financial commitment that I'm not sure I'm ready for right now. Renting allows me to focus on my work, my community, and my personal growth without the added pressure of a mortgage. I live in a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for decades, and while it's not the newest place, it has a lot of character and feels like home. I like knowing that if I ever need to make a change, I can do so without the hassle of selling a house or dealing with the uncertainties of the housing market.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Michael Romero: Over the past year, my bills have had their usual ups and downs, depending on the season and what's going on in my life. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill tends to go up a bit, and I also spend more on groceries since I'm cooking more at home and trying to eat seasonally. I also noticed that my car maintenance costs increased a little last spring when I had to replace the brakes, which was an unexpected expense. On the other hand, during the summer, I spend a bit more on outdoor activities—like buying plants for my balcony garden or going to the park more often. Holidays also bring some changes, especially around Christmas when I tend to spend a little more on gifts for my family and friends, even if it's just a small token. I also have to factor in the occasional unexpected costs, like a new pair of shoes or a replacement for something broken. But overall, I've been pretty consistent with my budget, and I try to plan ahead for these fluctuations so I don't get caught off guard. It's not always perfect, but I've learned to be flexible and adjust as needed.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how much my family and my approach to connection—both in person and through technology—continue to shape my sense of identity and well-being. My parents and sister have remained a constant source of support and love, even as we've all navigated different stages of life. Their growth and reflection have reminded me of the importance of staying connected, even when life pulls us in different directions. At the same time, I've come to appreciate that my choice to limit my presence on social media isn't a lack of connection, but rather a conscious decision to prioritize meaningful, in-person relationships over the noise of the digital world. I've found that the people I know and love—whether through family, friends, or my faith—are more than enough to help me through life's challenges. It's a reminder that while the world may be changing, the values I hold dear—family, community, and authenticity—remain the foundation of who I am.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Michael Romero: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. I've always believed that having a financial cushion is important, especially in case of unexpected expenses or if I ever need to make a big life change. Right now, I set aside about $300 a month into my savings, which I keep in a basic checking account with a separate savings portion. I don't have a high-interest savings account or anything fancy—I think simplicity is better for me. I also have a small emergency fund, which I've built up over the years by being careful with my spending and avoiding unnecessary debt. I know not everyone has the luxury of saving, and I'm grateful that I've been able to maintain this habit. It's not about being rich; it's about having peace of mind, knowing that I'm prepared for whatever comes next.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Michael Romero: For me, saving in the last year has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I've always felt that life can be unpredictable, and having a financial cushion gives me peace of mind. While I've considered buying a home at some point, I don't think I'm ready for that kind of commitment right now. Renting allows me the flexibility to move if needed, whether for a new job opportunity or just a change of scenery. My savings are more about covering emergencies, like a sudden medical expense or a car repair, which I know can happen without warning. I also try to save a little for small indulgences—like a nice meal out with Antonio or a new book from the library. It's not about luxury, but about enjoying the little things in life without feeling guilty. I think this approach has worked well for me, and I'm grateful that I've been able to maintain this habit without sacrificing the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Michael Romero: I've been working as a business analyst for a mid-sized financial services company, and my role has always been about making sense of data and helping organizations make informed decisions. The most important activities in my job involve analyzing trends, identifying inefficiencies, and proposing solutions that can improve processes or save costs. I spend a lot of time reviewing reports, meeting with different departments to understand their needs, and collaborating with teams to implement changes. One of the things I've always appreciated about this line of work is that it requires both analytical thinking and communication skills—being able to translate complex data into clear insights that others can use. I've also had the opportunity to work on a few long-term projects that have given me a sense of accomplishment, especially when I see the positive impact of my work. While it's not the most exciting job in the world, it's steady, and it allows me to use the skills I developed in college. I've always believed that work should be meaningful, and for me, that means finding ways to contribute, even in small ways, to the success of the organizations I serve.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Michael Romero: I usually work around 40 hours a week, Monday through Friday, though the exact hours can vary a bit depending on the project or deadlines. Most of my time is spent in the office, but I do have some flexibility with my schedule, which I appreciate. I start around 8 a.m. and typically leave around 5 p.m., though I've been known to stay a little later on busy days. What I like about my job is that it gives me a good work-life balance—I can leave on time and still have time for my routines, like attending Mass, volunteering, or catching up with Antonio for a drink. I've always believed that work should support your life, not take over it, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay grounded and focused on the things that really matter to me.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Michael Romero: No, I've only ever had one job throughout my career. After college, I took the leap to Chicago and worked at that startup for a few years before moving back to Hoboken and settling into my current role as a business analyst. I've always believed in focusing on one thing at a time, and I think that's why I've been able to build a stable and fulfilling career without the stress of juggling multiple jobs. Plus, I've always valued the work-life balance that comes with having a single, full-time position. It allows me to be present for the things that matter most—my family, my faith, and my community. I've never felt the need to take on extra work for the sake of it, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay grounded and content with my life.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, I realize how much my approach to stress, financial stability, and connection with others has shaped my sense of balance and peace in life. Managing stress has become more intentional for me, and I've learned to lean on my faith, my friendships, and simple routines like walking by the river or journaling to stay grounded. At the same time, my financial habits—renting instead of owning, budgeting carefully, and saving consistently—have given me the freedom to live independently without the burden of debt or the pressure of a mortgage. I've also come to appreciate that my choice to limit my use of social media isn't a lack of connection, but a conscious decision to prioritize meaningful, in-person relationships over the noise of the digital world. My family, friends, and community continue to be the foundation of my life, and I'm grateful for the stability and support they provide. It's a reminder that while life has its challenges, the choices I've made—about work, money, and connection—have helped me build a life that feels meaningful, secure, and deeply rooted in the values that have always guided me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Michael Romero: In terms of income, my household made around $5,200 last month. I work full time as a business analyst, and while it's not a high-paying job, it's stable and allows me to live comfortably in Hoboken. I've always been careful with my money, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to maintain a good quality of life without the stress of financial instability. I also have some income from a small side project I started a few years back—writing articles for a local Catholic magazine. It's not a major source of income, but it gives me a sense of purpose and allows me to share my faith and values with others. I try to live within my means, and I've always believed that having a steady income, even if it's not extravagant, is more than enough to build a meaningful life.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Michael Romero: I've been at my current job for nearly a decade now, and I've really come to appreciate the stability it offers. The company provides a good benefits package, including health insurance, dental, and vision coverage, which is something I'm grateful for, especially as I've gotten older and more aware of the importance of regular check-ups and preventive care. We also get a standard amount of paid time off—about three weeks of vacation, plus sick days and holidays. I've always valued the flexibility that comes with this, because it allows me to take time for family, my faith, and my community without worrying about losing pay. One of the things I like most about the workplace is the culture—it's professional but not overly rigid, and there's a real emphasis on teamwork and collaboration. I've had the chance to work with some great people over the years, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay in this role for so long. It's not the most exciting job in the world, but it's steady, and that's something I value a lot in life.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Michael Romero: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I've always believed in building trust and mutual respect, and I think that's something that comes through in how I interact with my manager and coworkers. My manager is someone I respect a lot—she's been with the company for over 20 years, and she has a deep understanding of the industry. She's supportive, gives clear direction when needed, and she's always been open to hearing my ideas. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to grow in my role over the years. As for my coworkers, I've always found them to be a good mix of professional and friendly. We work well together, and while we're all focused on getting the job done, there's a sense of camaraderie that makes the workplace feel like a team rather than just a group of people doing their jobs. I've had some really good mentors over the years, and I think that's part of why I've stayed in this field for so long. It's not just about the work itself—it's about the people you work with and the environment you're in. I've always felt lucky to be part of a team that values collaboration and growth.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Michael Romero: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though I do have some flexibility depending on the project. I usually start around 8 a.m. and leave around 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay a bit later to wrap up a task or meet a deadline. The company allows for some remote work, especially when needed, which I appreciate because it gives me the option to work from home if I need to rest or take care of something personal. That said, I've always preferred being in the office because I find that I'm more focused and productive when I'm surrounded by colleagues and the routine of going in and out of the building. I think the predictability of the schedule is one of the things I value most—it gives me a sense of structure that helps me balance my work with my personal life, whether it's attending Mass, volunteering, or just enjoying the quiet moments by the river.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Michael Romero: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. I know I'm not wealthy, but I've always believed that financial security is about more than just having a lot of money—it's about having enough to live comfortably, to support the things that matter most, and to have a sense of independence. I've been careful with my spending, and I've always made sure to save a little each month, which gives me peace of mind. I don't have any major debts, and I've been able to maintain a stable life without the stress of financial instability. I also appreciate that my job provides a steady income and good benefits, which allows me to focus on my work, my faith, and my community without worrying about the next paycheck. I know there are people who have it much harder than I do, and I'm grateful for the opportunities I've had. For me, financial stability isn't about luxury—it's about freedom, and I feel like I have that.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40, I realize how much my financial habits, work-life balance, and approach to stability have shaped my sense of security and peace in life. Managing my bills, saving consistently, and maintaining a predictable work schedule have given me the freedom to live independently without the burden of debt or the pressure of financial instability. I've come to appreciate that my choice to focus on one job, rent instead of own, and live within my means has allowed me to build a life that feels meaningful and secure. It's a reminder that while life has its challenges, the choices I've made—about money, work, and balance—have helped me create a foundation that supports my values, my family, and my sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Michael Romero: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father worked as a mechanic at a local garage, and my mother was a school administrator in Hoboken. They both worked full-time, though they never had advanced degrees. My father's job was demanding—he often worked long hours, especially during the winter months when car maintenance was at its peak. My mother, on the other hand, had a more structured schedule, but she was always dedicated to her work and to making sure my siblings and I had everything we needed. I remember seeing them both sacrifice a lot to give us opportunities they never had. They never talked about money much, but I could tell they were always careful with it. My mother would often say, 'We may not have a lot, but we have what we need,' and I think that mindset shaped the way I view money and success today. It's one of the reasons I've always been careful with my own finances and why I value stability and independence so much.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Michael Romero: My father worked as a mechanic at a local garage in Hoboken, and his most important duties involved repairing cars, doing oil changes, and handling everything from brake jobs to engine repairs. He was a hands-on kind of guy, always getting his hands dirty, and he had a real knack for figuring out what was wrong with a car just by listening to it. He worked long hours, especially during the winter when people needed their cars fixed before the snow started falling. My mother, on the other hand, was a school administrator—she worked at a public school in Hoboken, and her job involved managing staff, organizing events, and making sure everything ran smoothly. She was very organized and had a strong sense of responsibility. I remember her staying late at the school on many nights, especially during the school year, to handle paperwork or meet with parents. Both of them worked hard, and they never complained about it. They always made sure that my siblings and I had what we needed, even if it meant sacrificing their own time or money. I think that's why I've always valued hard work and responsibility—it wasn't just something they taught me; it was something they lived every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Michael Romero: My father worked for a local auto repair shop that was owned by a family friend, and it was a small, family-run business. They did everything from routine maintenance to major repairs, and my father was one of the main mechanics there. He was respected in the community, and people would often bring their cars to him because they knew he was reliable and honest. My mother worked for the Hoboken Public School District as an administrator, which meant she was responsible for managing the day-to-day operations of the school—scheduling, budgeting, staff coordination, and making sure that everything ran smoothly for the students and teachers. She was very detail-oriented and had a real passion for education. I remember her working late into the evenings, especially during the school year, and she always made sure that the needs of the students and staff were met. Both of them were proud of their work, and they always made it clear that hard work and responsibility were important values to live by. I think that's why I've always taken my own work seriously—it wasn't just something I learned from them; it was something I saw them do every day.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Michael Romero: Looking ahead, I hope to continue living the life I've built in Hoboken—one that feels meaningful, grounded, and aligned with my values. I don't see myself making any drastic changes, but I do hope to continue growing in the ways that matter most to me. I'd like to keep volunteering at the food pantry, maybe even take on a small leadership role there, and I hope to deepen my connection with my faith through more community involvement. I also want to keep nurturing my balcony garden and find joy in the small, everyday moments that bring me peace. Professionally, I'd like to stay in my current role for a while longer, maybe even mentor someone new to the field, as I've had some great mentors over the years. I don't have any grand ambitions or dreams of moving to another city or changing careers—I think I've found my place, and I'm content with that. I hope to continue enjoying the quiet stability of my life, surrounded by the people I care about, and to keep making choices that reflect who I am and what I believe in. At the same time, I know life is unpredictable, and I hope to stay open to whatever comes next, whether it's a new opportunity, a challenge, or just another day by the river with a good book in hand.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Michael Romero: What I value the most in my life is the sense of peace and purpose that comes from living in alignment with my beliefs, my community, and the people I care about. I value my faith deeply—it's not just about going to Mass on Sundays, but about the way it shapes how I treat others, how I approach challenges, and how I find meaning in everyday life. I also value the relationships I have with my family and friends, especially the ones that have stood by me through the years, like Antonio or my parents. They remind me that no matter how much life changes, the connections we build are what truly matter. I value the quiet stability of my life in Hoboken, the sense of belonging in my neighborhood, and the ability to live independently without the burden of debt or financial instability. I value the small joys—the smell of fresh bread from the bakery, the sound of the river in the morning, the satisfaction of tending to my garden. And I value the freedom to make choices that reflect who I am, rather than what others expect of me. It's not about perfection; it's about living with intention, with gratitude, and with the understanding that life is a journey, not a destination.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45, I realize how much my financial stability, work-life balance, and relationships at work have shaped my sense of security and fulfillment. My income, while modest, is enough to live comfortably in Hoboken, and I've always been careful with my money, which has given me the freedom to live independently without the burden of debt. My job as a business analyst has provided me with a steady income and good benefits, which I appreciate, especially as I've grown older and more aware of the importance of health and stability. The predictability of my work schedule allows me to maintain a routine that includes attending Mass, volunteering, and spending time with friends like Antonio, all of which contribute to my sense of purpose. My relationships at work are positive and supportive, and I've always valued the teamwork and collaboration that come with my role. It's not the most exciting job in the world, but it's steady, and that's something I value a lot in life. I've come to understand that financial security and a stable work environment are not just about comfort—they're about the freedom to live according to my values and priorities, and I'm grateful for the life I've built.

Looking back on the complete interview and life story, I realize how deeply interconnected my experiences, values, and choices have been throughout my life. From my childhood in Hoboken, shaped by the hard work and sacrifices of my parents, to the pivotal decision to move to Chicago and embrace a new path, each step has led me to where I am today. I've come to understand that my journey is not just about the decisions I've made, but also about the people who have supported me along the way—my family, my friends, and the community that has always felt like home. I've chosen a life of independence, stability, and purpose, and while it may not be the path others might have expected for me, it is one that aligns with who I am and what I value most. I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned, the challenges I've faced, and the sense of fulfillment that comes from living with intention and faith. This life story, with all its ups and downs, has shaped me into the person I am today, and I feel a deep sense of peace knowing that I've built a life that feels meaningful and true to myself.
